data_findings.finding: This is a 2D polygon packing problem: pack Christmas tree shapes (15-vertex polygons) into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200 trees. Score = sum(side^2/N). Lower is better. Target: 68.894234. Tree shape: trunk (0.15w x 0.2h), 3 tiers (base 0.7w, mid 0.4w, top 0.25w), tip at y=0.8.

Key approaches from kernels: 1) bbox3.cpp - C++ optimizer using simulated annealing with complex number vectors, fluid dynamics, hinge pivot, density gradient flow, global boundary tension. 2) shake_public - external compiled tool for optimization. 3) Rotation optimization using convex hull and minimize_scalar. 4) Greedy initial placement with weighted angles (sin(2*angle) distribution favors corners).

Discussion insights from titles: 1) 'Why winning solutions will be Asymmetric' (38 votes) - asymmetric solutions outperform symmetric. 2) 'Symmetric solutions that are apparently optimal' (43 votes) - debate about symmetric vs asymmetric. 3) Tessellations are important for efficient packing. 4) Per-N optimization is key - different strategies for different N values.

Academic approaches for 2D irregular packing: 1) No-fit polygon (NFP) - precompute collision-free regions for O(1) overlap checks. 2) Simulated annealing with collision-free region placement. 3) Hybrid genetic algorithm + linear programming. 4) Jostle algorithm - iterative repacking from alternating ends. 5) Multi-level algorithms with collision-free regions. Key insight: NFP enables efficient geometry handling.

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for irregular polygon packing optimization in 2D?
web_research.finding:
The best algorithms for irregular polygon packing optimization in 2D generally fall into categories such as heuristics, metaheuristics, and exact methods, with recent research emphasizing hybrid approaches. For instance, a hybrid approach combining genetic algorithms with linear programming has shown promising results in optimizing irregular packing problems, effectively handling complex shape arrangements ([MDPI](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/13/22/12474)). Additionally, simulated annealing-based algorithms have been successfully applied to irregular shape packing, demonstrating the ability to improve solutions and update best-known results on benchmark problems ([Sato et al., 2011](https://skoge.folk.ntnu.no/prost/proceedings/ifac11-proceedings/data/html/papers/0563.pdf)). 

Other notable methods include local search heuristics and multi-level algorithms that incorporate collision-free regions, which are effective in managing irregular shapes and minimizing waste ([Abeysooriya et al

web_research.query: What are tessellation patterns for packing identical irregular shapes efficiently?
web_research.finding:
Tessellation patterns for packing identical irregular shapes efficiently involve arranging shapes in a way that covers a surface without gaps or overlaps. While regular tessellations typically use polygons like triangles, squares, or hexagons, irregular shapes can also tessellate if they meet certain conditions. For example, all triangles and quadrilaterals can tessellate regardless of their specific shape, and some irregular pentagons are capable of tessellating, with only 15 types proven to do so ([studypug](https://www.studypug.com/us/grade6/understand-tessellations); [mathcuriosity](https://www.mathcuriosity.com/tessellations)). 

Efficient packing of irregular shapes often employs heuristic and optimization approaches, such as continuous and combinatorial optimization, to improve surface coverage and tile arrangement.
